technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: MuddyWater has disguised malicious executables and used filenames and Registry key names associated with Windows Defender.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Mustang Panda has used names like adobeupdate.dat and PotPlayerDB.dat to disguise PlugX, and a file named OneDrive.exe to load a Cobalt Strike payload.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Naikon has disguised malicious programs as Google Chrome, Adobe, and VMware executables.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Nebulae uses functions named StartUserModeBrowserInjection and StopUserModeBrowserInjection indicating that it's trying to imitate chrome_frame_helper.dll.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: NETWIRE has masqueraded as legitimate software including TeamViewer and macOS Finder.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: NightClub has chosen file names to appear legitimate including EsetUpdate-0117583943.exe for its dropper.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: NOKKI is written to %LOCALAPPDATA%\MicroSoft Updatea\svServiceUpdate.exe prior being executed in a new process in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate folder and file.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Octopus has been disguised as legitimate programs, such as Java and Telegram Messenger.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: OLDBAIT installs itself in %ALLUSERPROFILE%\Application Data\Microsoft\MediaPlayer\updatewindws.exe; the directory name is missing a space and the file name is missing the letter "o."

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: During Operation CuckooBees, the threat actors renamed a malicious executable to rundll32.exe to allow it to blend in with other Windows system files.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: During Operation Honeybee, the threat actors used a legitimate Windows executable and secure directory for their payloads to bypass UAC.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: During Operation Sharpshooter, threat actors installed Rising Sun in the Startup folder and disguised it as mssync.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: During Operation Wocao, the threat actors renamed some tools and executables to appear as legitimate programs.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: OSX/Shlayer can masquerade as a Flash Player update.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: OwaAuth uses the filename owaauth.dll, which is a legitimate file that normally resides in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\Auth\; the malicious file by the same name is saved in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\bin\.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Patchwork installed its payload in the startup programs folder as "Baidu Software Update." The group also adds its second stage payload to the startup programs as "Net Monitor." They have also dropped QuasarRAT binaries as files named microsoft_network.exe and crome.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PcShare has been named wuauclt.exe to appear as the legitimate Windows Update AutoUpdate Client.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Penquin has mimicked the Cron binary to hide itself on compromised systems.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PipeMon modules are stored on disk with seemingly benign names including use of a file extension associated with a popular word processor.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PlugX has been disguised as legitimate Adobe and PotPlayer files.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Pony has used the Adobe Reader icon for the downloaded file to look more trustworthy.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Poseidon Group tools attempt to spoof anti-virus processes as a means of self-defense.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PowGoop has used a DLL named Goopdate.dll to impersonate a legitimate Google update file.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PROMETHIUM has disguised malicious installer files by bundling them with legitimate software installers.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PUNCHBUGGY mimics filenames from %SYSTEM%\System32 to hide DLLs in %WINDIR% and/or %TEMP%.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: PyDCrypt has dropped DCSrv under the svchost.exe name to disk.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Pysa has executed a malicious executable by naming it svchost.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: QUADAGENT used the PowerShell filenames Office365DCOMCheck.ps1 and SystemDiskClean.ps1.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: QUIETEXIT has attempted to change its name to cron upon startup. During incident response, QUIETEXIT samples have been identified that were renamed to blend in with other legitimate files.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Raindrop was installed under names that resembled legitimate Windows file and directory names.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: RainyDay has used names to mimic legitimate software including "vmtoolsd.exe" to spoof Vmtools.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Ramsay has masqueraded as a 7zip installer.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: RDAT has masqueraded as VMware.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: The Remsec loader implements itself with the name Security Support Provider, a legitimate Windows function. Various Remsec .exe files mimic legitimate file names used by Microsoft, Symantec, Kaspersky, Hewlett-Packard, and VMWare. Remsec also disguised malicious modules using similar filenames as custom network encryption software on victims.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: REvil can mimic the names of known executables.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Rocke has used shell scripts which download mining executables and saves them with the filename "java".

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: RotaJakiro has used the filename systemd-daemon in an attempt to appear legitimate.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Ryuk has constructed legitimate appearing installation folder paths by calling GetWindowsDirectoryW and then inserting a null byte at the fourth character of the path. For Windows Vista or higher, the path would appear as C:\Users\Public.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: S-Type may save itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service binary.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Saint Bot has been disguised as a legitimate executable, including as Windows SDK.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Sandworm Team has avoided detection by naming a malicious binary explorer.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Shark binaries have been named audioddg.pdb and Winlangdb.pdb in order to appear legitimate.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: ShimRatReporter spoofed itself as AlphaZawgyl_font.exe, a specialized Unicode font.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Sibot has downloaded a DLL to the C:\windows\system32\drivers\ folder and renamed it with a .sys extension.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SideCopy has used a legitimate DLL file name, Duser.dll to disguise a malicious remote access tool.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Sidewinder has named malicious files rekeywiz.exe to match the name of a legitimate Windows executable.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Silence has named its backdoor "WINWORD.exe".

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Skidmap has created a fake rm binary to replace the legitimate Linux binary.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SLOTHFULMEDIA has mimicked the names of known executables, such as mediaplayer.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Small Sieve can use variations of Microsoft and Outlook spellings, such as "Microsift", in its file names to avoid detection.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 renamed software and DLLs with legitimate names to appear benign.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Sowbug named its tools to masquerade as Windows or Adobe Reader software, such as by using the file name adobecms.exe and the directory CSIDL_APPDATA\microsoft\security.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: To establish persistence, SslMM identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an "Office Start," "Yahoo Talk," "MSN Gaming Z0ne," or "MSN Talk" shortcut.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Starloader has masqueraded as legitimate software update packages such as Adobe Acrobat Reader and Intel.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: StrifeWater has been named calc.exe to appear as a legitimate calculator program.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: StrongPity has been bundled with legitimate software installation files for disguise.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SUGARDUMP has been named CrashReporter.exe to appear as a legitimate Mozilla executable.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SUNBURST created VBScripts that were named after existing services or folders to blend into legitimate activities.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SUNSPOT was identified on disk with a filename of taskhostsvc.exe and it created an encrypted log file at C:\Windows\Temp\vmware-vmdmp.log.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: SUPERNOVA has masqueraded as a legitimate SolarWinds DLL.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: TA2541 has used file names to mimic legitimate Windows files or system functionality.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: The TAINTEDSCRIBE main executable has disguised itself as Microsoft’s Narrator.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Tarrask has masqueraded as executable files such as winupdate.exe, date.exe, or win.exe.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: TeamTNT has replaced .dockerd and .dockerenv with their own scripts and cryptocurrency mining software.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: TEARDROP files had names that resembled legitimate Window file and directory names.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: TEMP.Veles has renamed files to look like legitimate files, such as Windows update files or Schneider Electric application files.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: ThiefQuest prepends a copy of itself to the beginning of an executable file while maintaining the name of the executable.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: ThreatNeedle chooses its payload creation path from a randomly selected service name from netsvc.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: TinyTurla has been deployed as w64time.dll to appear legitimate.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Transparent Tribe can mimic legitimate Windows directories by using the same icons and names.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Tropic Trooper has hidden payloads in Flash directories and fake installer files.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Ursnif has used strings from legitimate system files and existing folders for its file, folder, and Registry entry names.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: USBStealer mimics a legitimate Russian program called USB Disk Security.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Volt Typhoon has used legitimate looking filenames for compressed copies of the ntds.dit database and used names including cisco_up.exe, cl64.exe, vm3dservice.exe, watchdogd.exe, Win.exe, WmiPreSV.exe, and WmiPrvSE.exe for the Earthworm and Fast Reverse Proxy tools.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: Whitefly has named the malicious DLL the same name as DLLs belonging to legitimate software from various security vendors.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: A Winnti for Windows implant file was named ASPNET_FILTER.DLL, mimicking the legitimate ASP.NET ISAPI filter DLL with the same name.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: WIRTE has named a first stage dropper Kaspersky Update Agent in order to appear legitimate.

technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
technique: ZLib mimics the resource version information of legitimate Realtek Semiconductor, Nvidia, or Synaptics modules.
Keydnap puts a space after a false .jpg extension so that execution actually goes through the Terminal.app program.
The Bazar loader has used dual-extension executable files such as PreviewReport.DOC.exe.
Milan has used an executable named companycatalog.exe.config to appear benign.
Mustang Panda has used an additional filename extension to hide the true file type.
During the 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack, Sandworm Team masqueraded executables as .txt files.
ANDROMEDA has been delivered through a LNK file disguised as a folder.
AvosLocker has been disguised as a .jpg file.
Brute Ratel C4 has used Microsoft Word icons to hide malicious LNK files.
During Operation Dream Job, Lazarus Group disguised malicious template files as JPEG files to avoid detection.
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D has disguised it's true file structure as an application bundle by adding special characters to the filename and using the icon for legitimate Word documents.
The QakBot payload has been disguised as a PNG file and hidden within LNK files using a Microsoft File Explorer icon.
Volt Typhoon has appended copies of the ntds.dit database with a .gif file extension.
AppleSeed can disguise JavaScript files as PDFs.
APT28 has renamed the WinRAR utility to avoid detection.
APT32 has disguised a Cobalt Strike beacon as a Flash Installer.
Bisonal dropped a decoy payload with a .jpg extension that contained a malicious Visual Basic script.
BoomBox has the ability to mask malicious data strings as PDF files.
BRONZE BUTLER has masked executables with document file icons including Word and Adobe PDF.
During C0015, the threat actors named a binary file compareForfor.jpg to disguise it as a JPG file.
During C0018, AvosLocker was disguised using the victim company name as the filename.
The Dacls Mach-O binary has been disguised as a .nib file.
DarkTortilla's payload has been renamed PowerShellInfo.exe.
DarkWatchman has used an icon mimicking a text file to mask a malicious executable.
Dragonfly has created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.
EnvyScout has used folder icons for malicious files to lure victims into opening them.
FatDuke has attempted to mimic a compromised user's traffic by using the same user agent as the installed browser.
FIN13 has masqueraded staged data by using the Windows certutil utility to generate fake Base64 encoded certificates with the input file.
Flagpro can download malicious files with a .tmp extension and append them with .exe prior to execution.
FoggyWeb can masquerade the output of C2 commands as a fake, but legitimately formatted WebP file.
Kimsuky has disguised its C2 addresses as the websites of shopping malls, governments, universities, and others.
LazyScripter has used several different security software icons to disguise executables.
menuPass has used esentutl to change file extensions to their true type that were masquerading as .txt files.
Milan has used an executable named companycatalogue to appear benign.
NativeZone has, upon execution, displayed a message box that appears to be related to a Ukrainian electronic document management system.
Nomadic Octopus attempted to make Octopus appear as a  Telegram Messenger with a Russian interface.
NotPetya drops PsExec with the filename dllhost.dat.
OilRig has used .doc file extensions to mask malicious executables.
For Operation Dust Storm, the threat actors disguised some executables as JPG files.
During Operation Honeybee, the threat actors modified the MaoCheng dropper so its icon appeared as a Word document.
PLATINUM has renamed rar.exe to avoid detection.
PowGoop has disguised a PowerShell script as a .dat file (goopdate.dat).
Raindrop was built to include a modified version of 7-Zip source code (including associated export names) and Far Manager source code.
Ramsay has masqueraded as a JPG image file.
RCSession has used a file named English.rtf to appear benign on victim hosts.
RTM has been delivered as archived Windows executable files masquerading as PDF documents.
Ryuk can create .dll files that actually contain a Rich Text File format document.
Saint Bot has renamed malicious binaries as wallpaper.mp4 and slideshow.mp4 to avoid detection.

During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 set the hostnames of their C2 infrastructure to match legitimate hostnames in the victim environment. They also used IP addresses originating from the same country as the victim for their VPN infrastructure.
SombRAT can use a legitimate process name to hide itself.
TA551 has masked malware DLLs as dat and jpg files.
TeamTNT has disguised their scripts with docker-related file names.
TrailBlazer has used filenames that match the name of the compromised system in attempt to avoid detection.
The TrickBot downloader has used an icon to appear as a Microsoft Word document.
WhisperGate has been disguised as a JPG extension to avoid detection as a malicious PE file.

Windshift has used icons mimicking MS Office files to mask malicious executables. Windshift has also attempted to hide executables by changing the file extension to ".scr" to mimic Windows screensavers.
WindTail has used icons mimicking MS Office files to mask payloads.
XCSSET builds a malicious application bundle to resemble Safari through using the Safari icon and Info.plist.
ZIRCONIUM has spoofed legitimate applications in phishing lures and changed file extensions to conceal  installation of malware.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: An APT28 loader Trojan adds the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: Attor's dispatcher can establish persistence via adding a Registry key with a logon script HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment "UserInitMprLogonScript" .

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: Cobalt Group has added persistence by registering the file name for the next stage malware under HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: JHUHUGIT has registered a Windows shell script under the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: KGH_SPY has the ability to set the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key to execute logon scripts.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
technique: Zebrocy performs persistence with a logon script via adding to the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts
technique: APT29 has installed a run command on a compromised system to enable malware execution on system startup.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts
technique: Cyclops Blink has the ability to execute on device startup, using a modified RC script named S51armled.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts
technique: Green Lambert can add init.d and rc.d files in the /etc folder to establish persistence.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts
technique: HiddenWasp installs reboot persistence by adding itself to /etc/rc.local.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts
technique: iKitten adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.

technique_name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Startup Items
technique: jRAT can list and manage startup entries.
APT29 has hijacked legitimate application-specific startup scripts to enable malware to execute on system startup.
Rocke has installed an "init.d" startup script to maintain persistence.
Depending on the Linux distribution and when executing with root permissions, RotaJakiro may install persistence using a .conf file in the /etc/init/ folder.
APT28 has collected files from network shared drives.
When it first starts, BADNEWS crawls the victim's mapped drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.
BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.
During C0015, the threat actors collected files from network shared drives prior to network encryption.
Chimera has collected data of interest from network shares.
CosmicDuke steals user files from network shared drives with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.
Egregor can collect any files found in the enumerated drivers before sending it to its C2 channel.
Fox Kitten has searched network shares to access sensitive documents.
Gamaredon Group malware has collected Microsoft Office documents from mapped network drives.
menuPass has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with net use and using Robocopy to transfer data.
Ramsay can collect data from network drives and stage it for exfiltration.
Sowbug extracted Word documents from a file server on a victim network.

During the 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack, Sandworm Team used BlackEnergy’s network sniffer module to discover user credentials being sent over the network between the local LAN and the power grid’s industrial control systems.

APT28 deployed the open source tool Responder to conduct NetBIOS Name Service poisoning, which captured usernames and hashed passwords that allowed access to legitimate credentials. APT28 close-access teams have used Wi-Fi pineapples to intercept Wi-Fi signals and user credentials.
APT33 has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.
DarkVishnya used network sniffing to obtain login data.
Emotet has been observed to hook network APIs to monitor network traffic.
Empire can be used to conduct packet captures on target hosts.

FoggyWeb can configure custom listeners to passively monitor all incoming HTTP GET and POST requests sent to the AD FS server from the intranet/internet and intercept HTTP requests that match the custom URI patterns defined by the actor.
Impacket can be used to sniff network traffic via an interface or raw socket.
Kimsuky has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols.

MESSAGETAP uses the libpcap library to listen to all traffic and parses network protocols starting with Ethernet and IP layers. It continues parsing protocol layers including SCTP, SCCP, and TCAP and finally extracts SMS message data and routing metadata.
NBTscan can dump and print whole packet content.
Penquin can sniff network traffic to look for packets matching specific conditions.
PoshC2 contains a module for taking packet captures on compromised hosts.
Regin appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.
Responder captures hashes and credentials that are sent to the system after the name services have been poisoned.
Sandworm Team has used intercepter-NG to sniff passwords in network traffic.
ADVSTORESHELL exfiltrates data over the same channel used for C2.
Amadey has sent victim data to its C2 servers.
AppleJeus has exfiltrated collected host information to a C2 server.
AppleSeed can exfiltrate files via the C2 channel.
APT3 has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.
APT32's backdoor has exfiltrated data using the already opened channel with its C&C server.
APT39 has exfiltrated stolen victim data through C2 communications.
Astaroth exfiltrates collected information from its r1.log file to the external C2 server.
Attor has exfiltrated data over the C2 channel.
AuTo Stealer can exfiltrate data over actor-controlled C2 servers via HTTP or TCP.
Adversaries can direct BACKSPACE to upload files to the C2 Server.
BADHATCH can exfiltrate data over the C2 channel.
Bandook can upload files from a victim's machine over the C2 channel.
Bankshot exfiltrates data over its C2 channel.
Bisonal has added the exfiltrated data to the URL over the C2 channel.
BLINDINGCAN has sent user and system information to a C2 server via HTTP POST requests.
BLUELIGHT has exfiltrated data over its C2 channel.

Bumblebee can send collected data in JSON format to C2.
During C0017, APT41 used its Cloudflare services C2 channels for data exfiltration.
